name: UbiquityDevSummit Extended
description:
Let's gather and watch the Ubiquity Dev Summit live from San Francisco together!
The summits agenda can be found here: https://ubiquity.withgoogle.com/

Topics of the summit are things like AndroidTV, AndroidWear, AndroidAuto, Cast, Tango and much more.
Reading the schedule, we can expect some big Brillo/Weave (Android for IoT) announcements at this event ;)

The keynote starts at 7pm (which is 10am PST).

We are in talks for a location, but it's not final yet.

Join us this evening for a interesting program and a good chat with other developers about all the different incarnations of Android!

name: May the source be with you.
description:
This will be the first "real" meetup in 2016.

Since Lightsabers should have a fingerprint protection, we'll cover this!
The second talk is about generating code using the force(annotation processing)Â 

Speakers:
Fingerprint API - Marvin Ramin(mytaxi)

Annotation Processing - Niklas Baudy(familo)

name: "Who's that guy next to me?"
description:
Did you:

â€¢Â ever wanted to know who's that guy there in the meetup?

â€¢Â ever wanted to talk to someone within the meetup, but after the event itself everyone just disappeared?

â€¢ work too much and need a breakÂ containing some drinks and fun?

Well, this event is supposed to give you the opportunity to do so!

This is a social event, there will be no speaker.

name: When defaults are not enough
description:
Hey Droids!

It's time for our next meetup, and this time we are going wild with new tools and customization. This event will be all about going that extra mile when the Android Framework is just not enough.

So here are the talks:

"Custom views magic" - Android SDK has a predefined set of views for interacting with the user and displaying various types of data. But sometimes your app has unique needs that arenâ€™t covered by the built-in views. In this talk we will consider how to create own views that are robust and reusable. by Sasha Kravchenko (Android Developer at car2go).

"Succumb to the Kotlin side" - Brief introduction to Kotlin explaining advantages of the language. by Alberto Ballano (Android Developer at XING).

name: Timey Wimey Nougat(?)
description:
Let's meet again to exchange and listen to some interesting Android development topics. This time around we will meet at the new Inovex Hamburg Office and have 2 tech talks.

We will get a bit timey wimey with aÂ Introduction to Android Wear watchfacesÂ byÂ Dionysis LorentzosÂ (Android Developer at car2go).

And after that Marvin Ramin (Android Developer at car2go) will tell us how toÂ Get Started with N Â 

Btw: What do you think N stands for?

name: The usual suspects...
description:
It's been a while since our last meetup.

Topics:

Are you Coordinating already?Â - Matthias Friedrich @ Jimdo

Retrolambda vs. Jack: Nobody is perfect - Serj Lotutovici @ XING

We're looking forward to see you!

name: Crazy Lumberjacks
description:
Yes! It's once again time for another awesome Android meetup. Leave your horses, cause we're driving into the woods Â with some Database wisdom. Afterwards you can share some insight about libraries, frameworks or just tell a crazy Android story and receive some amazing swag (Seriously you can't miss out on the swag).

Bring an axe! Â (Just kidding ;)

name: Android Meetup
description:
This time we are at Yelpâ€™s brandÂ new officeÂ in the Kaufmannshaus building in Neustadt. We will have food and drinks, along with two talks:

"Behavior Driven Development with Calabash for Android" by Teresa Holfeld (Android Developer @ Ubilabs)

We are looking forward to meet you all, exchange knowledge, network and have a drink together.

P.S. chances are good we will have a Google Pixel + Daydream Viewer and a Google Home to play around with at the event ;)

name: Christmas Event
description:
As we did this last year, we want to chill a bit at the end of the year, meet, have a few drinks and talk.

This year we would like to visit the Christmas Market in Altona.

We meet in front of Burger King. It would be really nice to hear your feedback for the last years meetup events, so that we can improve the meetups '17!

If you can't find us at the given location, give us a call: [masked]

name: Android Meetup - Ok Google, let's start into 2017
description:

Google Assistant API - Daniel Hartwich (XING AG)

???? - You!

name: Android Meetup - Making Things, the green way
description:
This time we are happy to welcome Wolfram Rittmeyer (Android GDE and well known Android techblogger) to give a talk about the latest incarnation of our favourite OS.

Â 1. TALK: "A whirlwind tour of Android Things"

Wolfram is giving an introduction into Android Things, how to get started, what you can do with it, and what APIs exist. You will also hear about where it differs from normal Android development and where the use of existing Android libraries and integration can help your IoT projects.

About Wolfram:

Wolfram Rittmeyer is a passionate Android-Developer and loves to share his knowledge. He has been writing articles about Android, is blogging on his blog Grokking Android, shares on Google+ and Twitter and talks about Android topics on devfests, user groups and conferences. Apart from Android he also has more than 15 years of experience with Java and JavaEE.

2. TALK: "Memory Leaks: What you donâ€™t know, WILL drive you crazy"Â by Omri Erez (Android Dev & Consultant)


Of course, as always, we are also looking forward to have a drink and a nice round of networking with you fellow Android people from Hamburg. Everyone is welcome :)

name: Android Meetup - #perfMatters & #serverless
description:
We have 2 great talks for you again this month.

After last month Omri Erez (Android Dev & Consultant)Â is doing it again. This time he will show and introduce us to the new Android Profiler in Android Studio 2.4,Â because you know: #perfMatters!

For the second talk we will go #serverless withÂ Tim Messerschmidt(Program Manager of Developer Relations DACH at Google) who is going to introduce us to Cloud Functions for Firebase. (WARNING: there is a high risk for this to be a JavaScript-heavy talk)

We are looking forward to meet you all again for some networking and interesting conversations in the 19th floor above the harbor and Elbe. ;)

name: Android Meetup - Consistency for Auth & UI
description:
After the I/O break (was it really a break?) we are back with two talks all about consistency! (yeah i know the twist is a bit far fetched, the talks don't really have anything in common ;P).

Nicola Corti (Android Developer @ Yelp) is going to talk about "Building UI Consistent Android Apps"

Consistency is probably one of the best known design principles.
Consistent UIs are easy to use, easy to learn and frustration free.
Nonetheless, they are also extremely easy to break! Just a few development iterations are enough to totally mess up your color palette or your icon sets.

Consistency gets even trickier if you have to ensure it across different Android apps. In such a scenario, defining style guides becomes crucial. Assets, icons, colors, metrics, and components should be easily accessible by developers/designers across your teams.
Furthermore, you must ensure that every style guide change will not break your app.

Yelp ships its experience across Android, iOS and Web apps used by millions of users. In this talk, you will get an insight into the challenges we face on a daily basis ensuring our visual consistency, and the solutions we adopted.


and Alexander Kreul (Android Developer @ Xing) will be talking about "Smartlock for Passwords on Android"

How to enable Smartlock for yourâ€‹ Users on Android to have them save their credentials on their Google account. Furthermore linking shared credentials from different apps or websites to offer a seamless login.


As always, we are looking forward to have a drink and a nice round of networking with you fellow Android people. See you at Yelp :)

name: Android Meetup - Intentious Smiles ðŸ˜€
description:
"Understanding Emojis" by Niklas Baudy (Android Developer @ Familonet)

Emojis are part of almost every app nowadays. In this talk, weâ€™ll get to know how Emojis started out, how they work under the hood and what is possible with them.
Weâ€™ll also look at the challenges that one needs to face when implementing custom Emojis support into their apps.


LIGHTNING TALKS

We are looking forward to meet you all for some networking and interesting conversations.

name: Android Meetup - further intentions
description:
After some long absence we are are happy to meet again at one of our first location hosts.

After we sadly had to cancel it last time we are catching up with onÂ Jossi Wolfs talk about the Model View IntentÂ architecture pattern.

In an age where testability and maintainability are some of the most important aspects in (Android) App development developers have been coming up with design patterns and own interpretations of them, for example MVP (Model View Presenter).

By decoupling business logic and platform-related code, code has been made more testable and easier to maintain.

A (relatively) new design pattern is MVI (Model View Intent). Being inspired by Facebookâ€™s Flux, it takes a lot from MVP and combines it with States and Intents.Intents are the user actions, e.g. tapping on a button, and States are generated and rendered by the View.

You will learn about the basic idea of MVI, what a State and State Reducer are, and how you can test applications with the MVI design pattern.


And the 2nd, smaller talk: Android App Shortcuts by Daniel Hartwich

name: Android Meetup @ Edeka
description:
Talks:

* A/B Testing - Muhammed Siddeek (Yelp)
* Experiences with BuddyBuild - Alexander Knauf (Edeka)

name: Christmas Droids
description:
After our big conference the DevFest Hamburg, let's meet one more time this year to come together, have a hot wine punch, chocolate or other tasty baverage at the christmas market and chat, network, be social and just have nice evening.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=967nio2LF7s

We will be meeting at 7pm in front of the townhall. Bring your friends, colleagues or whoever comes to your mind. There won't be a agenda or any other strict/technical content, just some nice people networking (which indeed tend to talk about green little droids pretty often ;) ).

We are looking forward to meet you and have a drink together.Â Â
how_to_find_us: We are meeting directly in front of the townhall.

name: Enlightening kick-off for 2018
description:
IMPORTANT:
The moovel office is no longer at the harbour!!!
They recently moved to the inner city.

The Entrance is on "Kurze MÃ¼hren 1", the elevator will bring you to the 5th Floor.

â€¢ What we'll do
To get 2018 going we start with several small lightning talks out of the community. Just come forth and tell us a few minutes about your latest learning, library, app or technology you worked on/with to inspire people and maybe make them aware of something they didn't know before. No need to have sophisticated slides or a completely figured out talk (although this is fine as well of course), it's also fine to just show some code in an IDE or hint to a project at GitHub.

For a start we will have 3 short talks:

Jossi Wolf: "Circular Reveal & Shared Elements"
In this talk, Jossi Wolf will talk about how he implemented a Google Play like transition with a circular reveal using shared elements.

AndrÃ© Tietz: "Flutter - a first look from the Android side "

Matthias Friedrich: "How to make your users rate your app"

â€¢ What to bring
A chatty mood and the will to learn.

â€¢ Important to know

name: Android Meetup
description:
It's time to meet again. So far we have one scheduled talk:

Doug Sillars: Its Time to Stop Stalling: Mobile App and Video Performance

Over 90% of mobile apps utilize network connections to download content. However, many apps have not fully optimized the transfer, causing delays and frustrating customers. In this talk, we'll look at how to profile the network transfers made in your mobile app or website, and walk through a number of best practices to identify and resolve. After this talk, you will know how to test for network inefficiencies, identify some common issues, and be able to resolve them in your code.

There is still room for a second talk, please approach us in case you want to present something.

See you soon.

name: Android Meetup
description:
We are going to have 2 talks.

Nicola Corty (Andtroid developer @Yelp):
"The Curious Case of Android Button"

We interact with buttons every day to get coffee, order pizza, or start a new Gradle build. They may look simple and straightforward, but they have a fundamental role in our environment: create a sense of power.

We all love to feel empowered and we all hate being frustrated by bad design. Your users know this as well, they want to feel immediately rewarded when they interact with your UI, and they will quickly drop your app if they get annoyed.

At Yelp, we get tens of millions button clicks a day. At that kind of scale, every pixel matters. We tune every single aspect of our buttons to make them simple and powerful, but adjusting every single shadow cast, click animation, or color layer can be tricky. In this talk, we will provide a deep dive into the Android framework and the Support Library to understand how buttons are rendered.

Dionysis Lorentzos (Android developer @car2go):
"Code scalability"

At the bottom line our jobs as developers is one: iterate or build quickly stable products. One might simply use for this the term "scalable code".

In this talk Dionysis will provide architectural insights about how we transformed the car2go app from a "monolith" to a modular, highly tested and adjustable app. We will also share the key decisions we made and experiences we learnt, over the last 3 years, in order to achieve this.

At the end of the talk, the attendee will know how to proceed with his codebase, even if his company suddenly decides to add 20 more people.

name: All About Architecture - September Android Meetup
description:
Hey Hamburg Droids!

After a summer break, we are meeting again to listen to talks and network (and have some drinks).

Natalya Blanco (Software Developer @Ubilabs) will talk about an architectural approach to multi-process synchronisation using RxJava.

Daniel Hartwich (Android Developer @XING) will talk about finding your way around with the new Architecture Navigation Component.

More details coming soon!

name: Testing Droids
description:
Long time no see, but its finally time to meet again. Let's mingle and listen to some testing matters ...

Danny Preussler (GDE for Android + Kotlin & mobile crafter @ sporttotal.tv) is coming over from Berlin to give a talk on Junit 5 and Android:

Abstract:
"Junit 5 is a big step for the world of (unit) testing. A new very flexible testing framework, based on learning from many years of Junit 4.
At sporttotal we use this for our Android unit tests and it changed the way we write tests. Hard for us to imagine living without features like @Nested.
But it is also a complete rewrite with breaking changes. How do you test on Android in a world without TestRunner and TestRules?
Let's walk through the Junit5 features. We'll look at what's new and why it was changed but with a special focus on Android and Kotlin."

Our 2nd talk comes from Nicola Corti (Android developer @ Yelp):
"I have no idea what my app is doing Â¯\_(ãƒ„)_/Â¯"

Abstract:
"Do you exactly know what's your app doing when you deliver it to your users? Are you 100% sure? Would you bet on this? You're probably confident with the code you wrote and you know what is doing.

But what about the code that others wrote?

We pull dependencies from the online repositories every day. Our applications strongly rely on external libraries that are hosted on public Maven repositories. What if one of those library contains some malicious code? Imagine a library that starts harvesting your user data without you knowing it.

In this talk we will see how to monitor and protect your application from malicious dependency on the web that might end up in your final compiled App."

As always: we are looking forward to meeting you all, get some interesting exchange and some fun networking.
